_exec_summary.SummaryText:
This is an executive summary of the policies, procedures, and activities for compliance with the EPA's Accidental Release Prevention Requirements - Risk Management Program pursuant to Title 40 Part 68 of the Code of Federal Regulations (40 CFR 68) for Kraft Heinz, Inc. Beaver Dam facility.



The accidental release prevention and emergency response policies at the stationary source [40 CFR 68.155(a)]:



The Kraft Heinz facility in Beaver Dam, Wisconsin has an excellent record in preventing and minimizing releases of anhydrous ammonia. The facility has implemented an electronic preventive maintenance system that uses a real time database to track training and inspection dates and issue reminders to responsible groups. The emergency response policies at this facility ensure that there is emergency response coverage, 24 hours - 7 days per week. There are also adequate provisions for coordination with outside agencies, such as with the Beaver Dam Fire Department, in the event of an emergency.



The stationary source and regulated substances handled [40 CFR 68.155(b)]:



Stationary Source, Regulated Substances Handles & Covered Process:



Kraft Heinz manufactures cream cheese and quality dips at the Beaver Dam facility. The North American Industry Classification System (NAICS) code for the primary process at this facility is (311513). Beaver Dam has one regulated substance under 40 CFR 68 and that is anhydrous ammonia (ammonia). Ammonia is used as refrigerant to keep the process and storage areas of the plant cold, so the products stay fresh and wholesome. Ammonia has been widely used as a refrigerant in the food industry for decades. The quantity of ammonia at Beaver Dam is approximately 40,000 pounds.



The general accidental release prevention program and chemical-specific prevention steps [40 CFR 68.155(c)]:



The Beaver Dam facility has taken all the necessary steps to comply with the accidental release prevention requirements set out under 40 Code of Federal

Regulations (CFR) Part 68 of the EPA. The required elements of the RMP prevention program are listed below:



?    Employee Participation 

?    Process Safety Information 

?    Process Hazard Analysis 

?    Operating Procedures 

?    Training 

?    Contractors 

?    Pre-startup Safety Review 

?    Mechanical Integrity 

?    Hot Work Permit 

?    Management of Change 

?    Incident Investigation 

?    Compliance Audits 

 

In addition, the facility meets the requirements of the RMP Emergency Planning and Response element as detailed below. These items, their specific requirements, and how the Beaver Dam facility complies with the requirements are addressed in the individual procedural documents. 



The five-year accident history [40 CFR 68.155(d)]: 



The Kraft Heinz Beaver Dam facility has had zero RMP reportable incidents in the previous five years. 



The emergency response program [40 CFR 68.155(e)]: 



The Beaver Dam facility developed an emergency response plan in which plant employees are divided into various management and response teams. The emergency response plan is made up of several different components. The main objective of the plan is to ensure that the facility emergency response is in compliance with OSHA and EPA to avoid injury to employees and impact to the community. The emergency response plan describes procedures to follow during natural and plant emergencies. Natural emergencies include tornado and thunderstorms while plant emergencies include fire and a chemical release. The plan includes a list of phone numbers for each plant specific emergency. Plant contacts with their corresponding phone numbers are listed. The emergency response plan contains an on-site contingency plan that was submitted to the Dodge County Board of Supervisors, and the Local Emergency Planning Committee, for review. The on-site contingency plan contains information about the frequency of employee personnel response training, training requirements, spill prevention techniques, an evacuati

on plan for the general public, SDS sheets for ammonia, and confined space entry procedures to name a few. During any incident, the Beaver Dam Fire Department will be called automatically to provide back-up emergency responders and equipment.



Planned changes to improve safety [40 CFR 68.155(f)]: 



The Beaver Dam facility is committed to continuous improvement and looks for opportunities to improve safety systems and programs at the facility.
